message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of genitourinary trauma with suprapubic tenderness and blood at the urethral meatus. Retrograde urethrogram is the best next step in assessing the extent of the injury. IV pyelogram and contrast-enhanced CT scan are not indicated in this case, and retroperitoneal ultrasound is not helpful in assessing urethral injuries.

Retrograde urethrogram is the next best step to evaluate for this injury. IV pyelogram and contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen are not necessary in this case. Retroperitoneal ultrasound would not be helpful in evaluating for a urethral injury.

Retrograde urethrogram is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis and plan management. IV pyelogram, contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen, and retroperitoneal ultrasound are not indicated for urethral injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and signs of a possible urethral injury, including suprapubic tenderness and blood at the urethral meatus. Retrograde urethrogram is the best next step in the management of this patient to assess for the potential urethral injury. IV pyelogram and retroperitoneal ultrasound are not indicated in this scenario. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen may be considered if there is suspicion of intra-abdominal injury or bleeding, but it would not be the best next step for this patient.

The best next step in management is to perform a retrograde urethrogram to assess for an urethral injury. The other options are less urgent or less appropriate for the patient’s presentation.
